[[Vertex figure]] represented as
3.5.3.5 or (3.5)2 |} In [[geometry]], a '''vertex configuration'''[http://www.math.technion.ac.il/S/rl/docs/uniform.pdf Uniform Solution for Uniform Polyhedra] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151127053535/http://www.math.technion.ac.il/S/rl/docs/uniform.pdf |date=2015-11-27 }} (1993)[http://www.mathconsult.ch/static/unipoly/unipoly.html The Uniform Polyhedra] Roman E. Maeder (1995)[https://books.google.com/books?id=nVx-tu596twC&lpg=PR4&ots=Eg73ne3jBW&dq=Steurer%20and%20Deloudi%202009%20Crystallography%20of%20quasicrystals%3A%20Concepts%2C%20methods%20and%20structures&pg=PA18#v=onepage&q=Archimedean%20tilings&f=false Crystallography of Quasicrystals: Concepts, Methods and Structures] by Walter Steurer, Sofia Deloudi, (2009) pp. 18–20 and 51–53[https://books.google.com/books?id=jBZ0AwAAQBAJ&lpg=PA16&ots=l4VX2MZvkU&dq=Cundy-Rollett%20%20archimedean%20dual&pg=PA20#v=snippet&q=vertex&f=false Physical Metallurgy: 3-Volume Set, Volume 1] edited by David E. Laughlin, (2014) pp. 16–20 is a shorthand notation for representing the [[vertex figure]] of a polyhedron or tiling as the sequence of faces around a vertex. For [[uniform polyhedron|uniform polyhedra]] there is only one vertex type and therefore the vertex configuration fully defines the polyhedron. ([[Chirality (mathematics)|Chiral]] polyhedra exist in mirror-image pairs with the same vertex configuration.) A vertex configuration is given as a sequence of numbers representing the number of sides of the faces going around the vertex. The notation "''a.b.c''" describes a vertex that has 3 faces around it, faces with ''a'', ''b'', and ''c'' sides. For example, "3.5.3.5" indicates a vertex belonging to 4 faces, alternating [[triangle]]s and [[pentagon]]s. This vertex configuration defines the [[vertex-transitive]] [[icosidodecahedron]]. The notation is cyclic and therefore is equivalent with different starting points, so 3.5.3.5 is the same as 5.3.5.3. The order is important, so 3.3.5.5 is different from 3.5.3.5. (The first has two triangles followed by two pentagons.) Repeated elements can be collected as exponents so this example is also represented as (3.5)2. It has variously been called a '''vertex description''',[https://www.uwgb.edu/dutchs/symmetry/archpol.htm Archimedean Polyhedra] Steven Dutch[http://www.orchidpalms.com/polyhedra/uniform/uniform.html Uniform Polyhedra] Jim McNeill[http://www.software3d.com/Uniform.php Uniform Polyhedra and their Duals] Robert Webb '''vertex type''',[http://hrcak.srce.hr/file/111177/ Symmetry-type graphs of Platonic and Archimedean solids], Jurij Kovič, (2011)[http://people.hws.edu/mitchell/tilings/part3.html 3. General Theorems: Regular and Semi-Regular Tilings] Kevin Mitchell, 1995 '''vertex symbol''',Resources for Teaching Discrete Mathematics: Classroom Projects, History, modules, and articles, edited by Brian Hopkins[http://polyhedra.mathmos.net/entry/vertexsymbol.html Vertex Symbol] Robert Whittaker '''vertex arrangement''',Structure and Form in Design: Critical Ideas for Creative Practice By Michael Hann '''vertex pattern''',[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/264848030_Symmetry-type_graphs_of_Platonic_and_Archimedean_solids Symmetry-type graphs of Platonic and Archimedean solids] Jurij Kovič '''face-vector'''.{{cite journal |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Michel_Deza/publication/2771104_Uniform_Partitions_of_3-Space_Their_Relatives_and_Embedding/links/00b49518d693ea2e99000000.pdf |title=Uniform Partitions of 3-space, their Relatives and Embedding |first1=Michel |last1=Deza |first2=Mikhail |last2=Shtogrin}} It is also called a '''[[Martyn Cundy|Cundy]] and Rollett symbol''' for its usage for the [[Archimedean solid]]s in their 1952 book ''Mathematical Models''.{{mathworld | urlname = ArchimedeanSolid | title = Archimedean solid }}[https://books.google.com/books?id=HjTSBQAAQBAJ&lpg=PA164&ots=BRizj1HDL-&dq=Cundy-Rollett%20symbol&pg=PA164#v=onepage&q=Cundy-Rollett%20symbol&f=false Divided Spheres: Geodesics and the Orderly Subdivision of the Sphere] 6.4.1 Cundy-Rollett symbol, p. 164[https://books.google.com/books?id=jBZ0AwAAQBAJ&lpg=PA16&ots=l4VX2MZvkU&dq=Cundy-Rollett%20%20archimedean%20dual&pg=PA20#v=snippet&q=%22Cundy%20and%20Rollett%20symbol%22&f=false Physical Metallurgy: 3-Volume Set, Volume 1] edited by David E. Laughlin, (2014) p. 16[https://books.google.com/books?id=aFDWuZZslUUC&lpg=PA111&ots=4qbQopCaeU&dq=Cundy%20and%20Rollett%20symbol&pg=PA111#v=onepage&q=Cundy%20and%20Rollett%20symbol&f=false CRC Concise Encyclopedia of Mathematics, Second Edition] By Eric W. Weisstein == Vertex figures == A ''vertex configuration'' can also be represented as a [[polygon]]al [[vertex figure]] showing the faces around the vertex. This ''vertex figure'' has a 3-dimensional structure since the faces are not in the same plane for polyhedra, but for [[uniform polyhedron|vertex-uniform polyhedra]] all the neighboring vertices are in the same plane and so this [[Orthographic projection|plane projection]] can be used to visually represent the vertex configuration. == Variations and uses == {| class=wikitable align=right style="text-align:center;" |+ Regular vertex figure nets, {''p'',''q''} = ''pq'' |- valign=bottom |[[File:Polyiamond-3-1.svg|80px]]
[[tetrahedron|{3,3}]] = 33
Defect 180° |[[File:Polyiamond-4-1.svg|80px]]

Defect 0° |- valign=bottom |[[File:TrominoV.jpg|80px]]
[[cube|{4,3}]]
Defect 90° |BGCOLOR="#e0e0ff"|[[File:Square tiling vertfig.png|80px]]
[[square tiling|{4,4}]] = 44
Defect 0° |[[File:Pentagon net.png|80px]]

Defect 36° |BGCOLOR="#e0e0ff"|[[File:Hexagonal tiling vertfig.png|80px]]
[[hexagonal tiling|{6,3}]] = 63
Defect 0° |- |colspan=4|A vertex needs at least 3 faces, and an [[angle defect]].
A 0° angle defect will fill the Euclidean plane with a regular tiling.
By [[Angular defect#Descartes.27 theorem|Descartes' theorem]], the number of vertices is 720°/''defect'' (4''&pi''; radians/''defect''). |} Different notations are used, sometimes with a comma (,) and sometimes a period (.) separator. The period operator is useful because it looks like a product and an exponent notation can be used. For example, 3.5.3.5 is sometimes written as (3.5)2. The notation can also be considered an expansive form of the simple [[Schläfli symbol]] for [[platonic solid|regular polyhedra]]. The Schläfli notation {''p'',''q''} means ''q'' ''p''-gons around each vertex. So {''p'',''q''} can be written as ''p.p.p...'' (''q'' times) or ''pq''. For example, an icosahedron is {3,5} = 3.3.3.3.3 or 35. This notation applies to polygonal tilings as well as polyhedra. A planar vertex configuration denotes a uniform tiling just like a nonplanar vertex configuration denotes a uniform polyhedron. The notation is ambiguous for [[Chirality (mathematics)|chiral]] forms. For example, the [[snub cube]] has clockwise and counterclockwise forms which are identical across mirror images. Both have a 3.3.3.3.4 vertex configuration. == Star polygons == The notation also applies for nonconvex regular faces, the [[star polygon]]s. For example, a [[pentagram]] has the symbol {5/2}, meaning it has 5 sides going around the centre twice. For example, there are 4 regular star polyhedra with regular polygon or star polygon vertex figures. The [[small stellated dodecahedron]] has the [[Schläfli symbol]] of {5/2,5} which expands to an explicit vertex configuration 5/2.5/2.5/2.5/2.5/2 or combined as (5/2)5. The [[great stellated dodecahedron]], {5/2,3} has a triangular vertex figure and configuration (5/2.5/2.5/2) or (5/2)3. The [[great dodecahedron]], {5,5/2} has a pentagrammic vertex figure, with ''vertex configuration'' is (5.5.5.5.5)/2 or (55)/2. A [[great icosahedron]], {3,5/2} also has a pentagrammic vertex figure, with vertex configuration (3.3.3.3.3)/2 or (35)/2. {| class=wikitable |[[File:Small stellated dodecahedron vertfig.png|150px]]||[[File:Great stellated dodecahedron vertfig.png|150px]] |[[File:Great snub icosidodecahedron vertfig.png|150px]] |[[File:Great retrosnub icosidodecahedron vertfig.png|150px]] |[[File:Small retrosnub icosicosidodecahedron vertfig.png|150px]] |- ![[small stellated dodecahedron|{5/2,5}]] = (5/2)5 ![[Great stellated dodecahedron|{5/2,3}]] = (5/2)3 ![[Great snub icosidodecahedron|34.5/2]] ![[Small retrosnub icosicosidodecahedron|34.5/3]] ![[Great retrosnub icosidodecahedron|(34.5/2)/2]] |- ||[[File:Great dodecahedron vertfig.png|150px]]||[[File:Great icosahedron vertfig.png|150px]] |[[File:DU57 facets.png|150px]] |[[File:DU72 facets.png|150px]] ||[[File:DU74 facets.png|150px]] |- ![[great dodecahedron|{5,5/2}]] = (55)/2 ![[great icosahedron|{3,5/2}]] = (35)/2 ![[Great pentagonal hexecontahedron|V.34.5/2]] ![[Small hexagrammic hexecontahedron|V34.5/3]] ![[Great pentagrammic hexecontahedron|V(34.5/2)/2]] |} == Inverted polygons == Faces on a vertex figure are considered to progress in one direction. Some uniform polyhedra have vertex figures with inversions where the faces progress retrograde. A vertex figure represents this in the [[star polygon]] notation of sides ''p/q'' such that ''p''<2''q'', where ''p'' is the number of sides and ''q'' the number of turns around a circle. For example, "3/2" means a triangle that has vertices that go around twice, which is the same as backwards once. Similarly "5/3" is a backwards pentagram 5/2. == All uniform vertex configurations of regular convex polygons == {{See also|Archimedean_solid#Classification|Tiling by regular polygons#Combinations of regular polygons that can meet at a vertex|Uniform tiling#Expanded lists of uniform tilings}} [[Semiregular polyhedron|Semiregular polyhedra]] have vertex configurations with positive [[Defect (geometry)|angle defect]]. NOTE: The vertex figure can represent a regular or semiregular tiling on the plane if its defect is zero. It can represent a tiling of the hyperbolic plane if its defect is negative. For uniform polyhedra, the angle defect can be used to compute the number of vertices. Descartes' theorem states that all the angle defects in a topological sphere must sum to 4''π'' radians or 720 degrees. Since uniform polyhedra have all identical vertices, this relation allows us to compute the number of vertices, which is 4''π''/''defect'' or 720/''defect''. Example: A [[truncated cube]] 3.8.8 has an angle defect of 30 degrees. Therefore, it has {{math|720/30 {{=}} 24}} vertices. In particular it follows that {''a'',''b''} has {{math| 4 / (2 - ''b''(1 - 2/''a''))}} vertices. Every enumerated vertex configuration potentially uniquely defines a semiregular polyhedron. However, not all configurations are possible. Topological requirements limit existence. Specifically ''p.q.r'' implies that a ''p''-gon is surrounded by alternating ''q''-gons and ''r''-gons, so either ''p'' is even or ''q'' equals ''r''. Similarly ''q'' is even or ''p'' equals ''r'', and ''r'' is even or ''p'' equals ''q''. Therefore, potentially possible triples are 3.3.3, 3.4.4, 3.6.6, 3.8.8, 3.10.10, 3.12.12, 4.4.''n'' (for any ''n''>2), 4.6.6, 4.6.8, 4.6.10, 4.6.12, 4.8.8, 5.5.5, 5.6.6, 6.6.6. In fact, all these configurations with three faces meeting at each vertex turn out to exist. The number in parentheses is the number of vertices, determined by the angle defect. ;Triples * Platonic solids [[tetrahedron|3.3.3]] (4), [[cube|4.4.4]] (8), [[dodecahedron|5.5.5]] (20) * [[prism (geometry)|prism]]s 3.4.4 (6), 4.4.4 (8; also listed above), 4.4.''n'' (2''n'') * Archimedean solids [[truncated tetrahedron|3.6.6]] (12), [[truncated cube|3.8.8]] (24), [[truncated dodecahedron|3.10.10]] (60), [[truncated octahedron|4.6.6]] (24), [[truncated cuboctahedron|4.6.8]] (48), [[truncated icosidodecahedron|4.6.10]] (120), [[truncated icosahedron|5.6.6]] (60). * regular tiling [[hexagonal tiling|6.6.6]] * semiregular tilings [[truncated hexagonal tiling|3.12.12]], [[truncated trihexagonal tiling|4.6.12]], [[truncated square tiling|4.8.8]] ;Quadruples * Platonic solid [[octahedron|3.3.3.3]] (6) * [[antiprism]]s 3.3.3.3 (6; also listed above), 3.3.3.''n'' (2''n'') * Archimedean solids [[cuboctahedron|3.4.3.4]] (12), [[icosidodecahedron|3.5.3.5]] (30), [[rhombicuboctahedron|3.4.4.4]] (24), [[rhombicosidodecahedron|3.4.5.4]] (60) * regular tiling [[square tiling|4.4.4.4]] * semiregular tilings [[trihexagonal tiling|3.6.3.6]], [[rhombitrihexagonal tiling|3.4.6.4]] ;Quintuples * Platonic solid [[icosahedron|3.3.3.3.3]] (12) * Archimedean solids [[snub cube|3.3.3.3.4]] (24), [[snub dodecahedron|3.3.3.3.5]] (60) (both [[Chirality (mathematics)|chiral]]) * semiregular tilings [[snub hexagonal tiling|3.3.3.3.6]] (chiral), [[Elongated triangular tiling|3.3.3.4.4]], [[snub square tiling|3.3.4.3.4]] (note that the two different orders of the same numbers give two different patterns) ;Sextuples * regular tiling [[triangular tiling|3.3.3.3.3.3]] == Face configuration == [[Image:Rhombic dodecahedron v3434.png|thumb|[[Rhombic dodecahedron]] ]] The uniform dual or [[Catalan solid]]s, including the [[bipyramid]]s and [[trapezohedra]], are ''vertically-regular'' ([[face-transitive]]) and so they can be identified by a similar notation which is sometimes called '''face configuration'''. Cundy and Rollett prefixed these dual symbols by a ''V''. In contrast, ''Tilings and Patterns'' uses square brackets around the symbol for isohedral tilings. This notation represents a sequential count of the number of faces that exist at each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]] around a [[face (geometry)|face]].Cundy and Rollett (1952) For example, V3.4.3.4 or V(3.4)2 represents the [[rhombic dodecahedron]] which is face-transitive: every face is a [[rhombus]], and alternating vertices of the rhombus contain 3 or 4 faces each. ==Tessellations== [[Spherical [[File:William Crawley-Boevey.jpg|thumb|William Crawley-Boevey at [[Mathematical Research Institute of Oberwolfach|Oberwolfach]], 2014]] '''William Walstan Crawley-Boevey''' (born 1960)<ref name="geneall">[http://geneall.net/en/name/2085073/william-walstan-crawley-boevey/ Geneall], retrieved 2015-01-16.</ref> is an English mathematician who is [[Professor]] of [[Pure Mathematics]] at the [[University of Leeds]].<ref>[http://www.maths.leeds.ac.uk/people.html Academic and Research Staff], School of Mathematics, University of Leeds, retrieved 2015-01-16.</ref> His research concerns [[representation theory]] and the theory of [[Quiver (mathematics)|quivers]].
Crawley-Boevey is the second son of [[Crawley-Boevey baronets|Sir Thomas Crawley-Boevey, 8th Baronet]].<ref name="geneall"/> He studied at the [[City of London School]] and read mathematics at [[St John's College, Cambridge]]. He received his [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] in 1986 from the [[University of Cambridge]] under the supervision of [[Stephen Donkin]].<ref>{{mathgenealogy|id=71333}}</ref> Before his appointment in Leeds, he held post-doctoral positions at the [[University of Liverpool]] and the [[University of Oxford]].
He was the 1991 winner of the [[Berwick Prize]] of the [[London Mathematical Society]].<ref>[http://www.lms.ac.uk/prizes/list-lms-prize-winners#Berwick Berwick Prize], List of LMS prize winners, [[London Mathematical Society]], retrieved 2015-01-16.</ref> In 2006, Crawley-Boevey presented an [[list of International Congresses of Mathematicians Plenary and Invited Speakers|invited talk at the International Congress of Mathematicians]].<ref>{{citation | last = Crawley-Boevey | first = William | contribution = Quiver algebras, weighted projective lines, and the Deligne-Simpson problem | mr = 2275591 | pages = 117–129 | publisher = Eur. Math. Soc., Zürich | title = International Congress of Mathematicians. Vol. II | year = 2006}}.</ref> In 2012, he became one of the inaugural [[fellow]]s of the [[American Mathematical Society]].<ref name="ams">{{cite web|url=http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list|publisher=ams.org|title=List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society|accessdate=2017-01-28}}</ref>

[[State Preeminent Science and Technology Award]] (2000) | footnotes = | module = {{Chinese |child=yes |t=吳文俊|s=吴文俊|p=Wú Wénjùn |w=Wu Wen-chün}} }} '''Wu Wenjun''' ({{zh|s=吴文俊}}; 12 May 1919 – 7 May 2017), also commonly known as '''Wu Wen-tsün''', was a Chinese [[mathematician]] and [[academician]] at the [[Chinese Academy of Sciences]] (CAS), best known for the [[Wu's method of characteristic set]]. ==Biography== Wu's [[Ancestral home (China)|ancestral hometown]] was [[Jiashan]], [[Zhejiang]]. He was born in [[Shanghai]] and graduated from [[National Chiao Tung University]] in 1940. In 1945, Wu taught several months at [[Zhijiang Campus, Zhejiang University|Hangchow University]] (later merged into [[Zhejiang University]]) in [[Hangzhou]]. In 1947, he went to [[France]] for further study at the [[University of Strasbourg]]. In 1949, he received his PhD, for his thesis ''Sur les classes caractéristiques des structures fibrées sphériques'', written under the direction of [[Charles Ehresmann]]. Afterwards, he did some work in Paris with [[René Thom]] and discovered the [[Wu class]] and [[Wu formula]] in algebraic topology. In 1951 he was appointed to a post at [[Peking University]]. However, Wu may have been among a wave of recalls of Chinese academics working in the West following [[Chiang Kai-shek]]'s ouster from the mainland in 1949, according to eyewitness testimony by [[Marcel Berger]], as he disappeared from France one day, without saying a word to anyone.{{Cite book| last1=Katz | first1=Mikhail G. | title=Systolic geometry and topology|url=https://books.google.com/?id=JuY5tsWAHoUC&pg=PA19&vq=pu&dq=Systolic+geometry+and+topology|page=19 | publisher=[[American Mathematical Society]] | location=Providence, R.I. | series=Mathematical Surveys and Monographs | isbn=978-0-8218-4177-8 | year=2007 | volume=137 | postscript=.}}. ==Honors and awards== In 1957, he was elected as an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. In 1986 he was an Invited Speaker of the [[International Congress of Mathematicians|ICM]] in Berkeley.{{cite book|author=Wu, Wen-tsün|chapter=Recent studies of the history of Chinese mathematics|title=''In:'' Selected Works Of Wen-Tsun Wu|pages=273–283|year=2008|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t2NhDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA273}} In 1990, he was elected as an academician of [[The World Academy of Sciences]] (TWAS). Along with [[Yuan Longping]], he was awarded the [[State Preeminent Science and Technology Award]] by President [[Jiang Zemin]] in 2000, when this highest scientific and technological prize in China began to be awarded. He also received the [[TWAS Prize]] in 1990{{Cite web |url=http://twas.org/opportunities/prizes-and-awards |title=Prizes and Awards |date=2016 |publisher=The World Academy of Sciences}} and the [[Shaw Prize]] in 2006. He was the President of the Chinese society of mathematics. He died on May 7, 2017, 5 days before his 98th birthday.{{Cite web|url=https://www.thepaper.cn/newsDetail_forward_1679596|title=首届国家最高科技奖得主、著名数学家吴文俊逝世，享年98岁|last=Zhang|first=Guo|date=2017-05-07|website=The Paper|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-15}} ==Research== The research of Wu includes the following fields: [[algebraic topology]], [[algebraic geometry]], [[game theory]], [[history of mathematics]], [[automated theorem proving]]. His most important contributions are to [[algebraic topology]]. The [[Wu class]] and the [[Wu formula]] are named after him. In the field of [[automated theorem proving]], he is known for [[Wu's method]]. He was also active in the field of the history of Chinese mathematics. He was the chief editor of the ten-volume Grand Series of Chinese Mathematics, covering the time from antiquity to late part of the [[Qin dynasty]]. ==Publications== *Wen-Tsun, Wu:Rational Homotopy Type: A Constructive Study Via the Theory of the I*-Measure {{ISBN|0-387-13611-8}} *Wen-tsun, Wu & Min-de, Cheng, CHINESE MATHEMATICS INTO THE 21ST CENTURY *Wen-tsun, Wu, A THEORY OF IMBEDDING IMMERSION AND ISOTOPY OF POLYTOPES IN A EUCLIDEAN SPACE *Wen-tsun, Wu,Mechanical Theorem Proving in Geometries. {{ISBN|3211825061}} *Wen-Tsun, Wu; Georges Reeb:Sur Les Espaces Fibres Et Les Varietes Feuilletees *SELECT WORKS OF WEN-TSUN WU {{ISBN|9789812791078}} *Wen-tsun, Wu: Mathematics Mechanization: Mechanical Geometry Theorem-Proving, Mechanical Geometry Problem-Solving and Polynomial Equations-Solving {{ISBN|0-7923-5835-X}} *Wen-Tsun, Wu, and Hu Guo-Ding, eds, Computer Mathematics {{ISBN|9810215282}} . ==References== * {{MathGenealogy |id=96086}} * {{MacTutor Biography|id=Wu_Wen-Tsun}} *{{Cite web| author=Wenjun Wu| title=Autobiography of Professor Wu Wentsun | url=http://www.shawprize.org/en/laureates/2006/mathematical/Mumford_Wu/autobiography/Wu.html | publisher=The Shaw Prize Foundation | year=2006 | accessdate=2007-09-16}} ==External links== *[http://www.mmrc.iss.ac.cn/~wtwu/ Wu's homepage ] {{zh icon}} {{Chinese Academy of Sciences}} {{Shaw Prize}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wu, Wenjun}} [[Category:1919 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:Chinese award winners]] [[Category:Chinese mathematicians]] [[Category:People's Republic of China science writers]] [[Category:Educators from Shanghai]] [[Category:Historians of mathematics]] [[Category:Members of the Chinese Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Peking University faculty]] [[Category:Topologists]] [[Category:Algebraic geometers]] [[Category:University of Strasbourg alumni]] [[Category:Writers from Shanghai]] [[Category:Zhejiang University faculty]] [[Category:Scientists from Shanghai]] [[Category:TWAS laureates]] [[Category:TWAS fellows]]
